job_title: Associate Producer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I was given a great amount of responsibility to increase our numbers amongst our demographics and I did that by employing social media marketing strategies. I appreciated that my ideas were heard during meetings. I appreciated the availability my boss, Jessica, created. She had a great open door policy that allowed access to her for any reason at all.
cons: It was not a downside for me as I was already making the commute in the afternoon, however if that commute was in the early morning hours, it would not have been feasible with my schedule. I would have needed some kind of flexibility in order to keep my employment status.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: work life balance is pretty good
cons: upward mobility is not terrible from what i hear

review_title: Stable job but you will be over worked and have few chances to grow
job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: Work from home, $18 start pay, yearly 3% raise guaranteed with no cap, Federal holidays off, end of year we are off for 2 weeks and it's paid, full sail (sister school) pays for a free trip to universal for holiday party (food and drinks covered), no quotas, no micromanaging, PTO, insurance, very hard to get fired
cons: Little to no growth opportunities, only 3% yearly raise which is roughly about 34 cents, inefficient processes, bad communication between departments, for profit school, quality of students is very low b/c we enroll anyone regardless of their previous academic background, nothing is automated like in other colleges so we do more work when it's not necessary, hard to make any changes to our process b/c most ideas are shot down, understaffed so the workload of 3 financial aid advisors is given to one person but they refuse to hire more people, no pay raises for added work load they just expect you to do it

job_title: Admissions Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: They pride in company outings. The office is very family oriented and allows a lot of free space to speak comfortably. With their wireless headphones you are able to move around and interview students comfortably
cons: Management needs to do better with micro managing.

job_title: Registrar Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Access to many events and screenings in Hollywood. Very diverse student body. CEO Tammy was extremely kind and very personable with the staff and student body.
cons: Pay could be a little more considering the workload.

job_title: Industry Relations in Los Angeles, CA
pros: All of the folks step up and really try and follow through with students
cons: Big organizations often don't have synergy between departments. It happens here.

review_title: Chill but a lot of people that refuse to do their job
job_title: Admissions Representative in Winter Park, FL
pros: Very chill environment if you meet your goals
cons: A lot of people are lazy and don't want to do their job

review_title: Wish I knew what I was getting into
job_title: Online Academic Advisor in Winter Park, FL
pros:
Paid holidays 
Gifts received during holidays
cons:

job_title: Admissions Representative in Winter Park, FL

- Company culture

review_title: Decent Job but not long-term if looking for growth
job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Winter Park, FL
pros:
Start pay $18
Yearly 3% raise
Job security (you have to really try to get fired)
Insurance (dental & vision included)
401K 
Mon-Fri schedule
OT options available on occassion
Federal Holidays are PTO
Co-workers are great people to work with!
cons:
Very few growth opportunities
Yearly raise is only 3% (roughly .54 cents) REGARDLESS of how well you did on your review
Only way to make more money is to be promoted and the options for that are extremely limited
Schedule is not flexible
Favortism present
Very few rewards for making monthly goals so team morale tends to be low
Some people in management have no management experience and it really shows
Some people in management have no financial aid experience but were promoted to a manager postion b/c of seniority
HR doesn't exist (i.e. they constantly have to hire a new HR person and every person who has been hired is there to protect the company 1st)

job_title: Counselor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Nothing is a pro if I am being completely and utterly honest and this is my honest opinion
cons:
Management is a poor interpretation of petty and very Mean Girls like. They favorite you if you are only a YES person. Pay is definitely a complete joke with $16-$18 starting with a possible 3% raise! Managers are complete idiots with no real knowledge of how a real school should be run to be successful. 


Google their retention rate! If we weren’t in a pandemic the rate would’ve been much higher than the embarrassing rate it is at

I promise you that you will get more work that your job title description
Do yourself a huge favor and run to the hill
 This school does not follow regulations and should not be continue to be running as it’s A for profit school

job_title: Global HR Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Location was great. Students were great.
cons: A lot of favoritism and unfair treatment

review_title: The best job I've had yet

You get to work remotely
Choose your office hours
Work life balance is a plus
Great benefits
cons: Not sure about pay raises or career advancement

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Orlando, FL
pros: Work from home, enjoyable pace, friendly coworkers, and more than competent management
cons: The work is easy and the people are nice.

job_title: Work Study Student in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The Events Department was made up of some of the most wonderful people. They are caring, driven, and served as great guidance during my time on the team.
cons: The number of members on the team was relatively low so I would have to shift responsibilities quite often.

job_title: Script Writer in Orlando, FL
pros: The best part of working for the online school was sharing a campus with Full Sail.
cons: Inept leadership caused all actual talent to leave. The company sent suits from LA to run the online program into the ground because it was making the campus in CA look bad.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Health insurance and security.
Good faculty and a nice work environment.
People are friendly.
cons:
Started teaching here with 8years experience and an MFA and I was given the same salary as someone with a Bachelors and no teaching experience.
Underpaid.
One of the better “for profit” schools out there but still has similar short comings as other schools of a similar nature.

job_title: Online Admissions Representative in Orlando, FL
pros:
- Team support: the team is very friendly, supportive, and flexible. 
- Communication: they do a really good job putting expectations out there
cons:
- Compensation: the job is not paid well at all compared to the amount of responsibility, it's sales with no commission
- Responsibilities and sales goals keep increasing more and more, and try to disguise as "it's the same as before but on different order" 
In reality youre doing more and are responsible for more

job_title: Instructor in Orlando, FL
pros: Diverse work force. Rewarding online instructor position but depends in which dept you work. Most are reasonable and caring managers. But there are those few strikingly mean managers to avoid. Glad I'm not in their dept.
cons: Online Instructor compensation low w/ 3% raises which does not cover health insurance increases - but health benefits are excellent. Can be a very rewarding instructor position unless you are in those few depts that have mean spirited managers.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Management cares about their employees. Good environment, employees are all very welcoming. Very much 'team work" oriented work place. Accumulated sick and vacation hours & good benefits. The school has handled covid19 with great care and concern for their employees. The school offers their employees to continue school with them and earn an online degree with their available programs. In return for the free education you must agree to remain employed with them at least 3 years after you've completed your online degree.
cons: Location: Not the worst location, just a few homeless people from time to time around the building. But that's just Hollywood.

Flexible work schedule
cons: Meeting arbitrary pass/fail requirements for accreditation does not make sense in the education sector.

review_title: Amazing Office but time to move on to better things.

review_title: Easiest job I've ever had but it's meticulous!

review_title: Good starter job, but the politics aren't worth it.
job_title: Admissions Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Solid benefits & flexible work schedule
cons: Too many in house politics, little to no room for advancement, favoritism, be wary of management, lack of accountability with management, etc.

review_title: Do not work here unless you are VERY desperate
job_title: Enrollment Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros: The job itself it actually really interesting.  The product is unique and you actually speak with interesting students who want to start a career in the entertainment business.
cons:
This really has to be the worst Admissions job in Orlando, which is a real shame because the product is very interesting.  It is a terrible work environment because of management. This is a classic example of somebody who was promoted because of sales numbers and not his people skills.  Management definitely comes off as buddy-buddy at first, but then will go 0 to 100 on you without warning.  It will honestly feel like you are back in 3rd grade and have a scary/mean teacher you're trying to avoid.  Everybody is walking on egg-shells

From the start, you will be told the salary is X amount of dollars, but he hides the fact that this is including 5 hours Overtime per week.  That means you have to work 45 hours per week to make what you are promised.  The big kicker here is that when you start, Overtime ends up not  being guaranteed. It will be up to the Director... if you are not hitting unrealistic numbers, he will not let you work OT (which is not the way It is presented during the interview).

Long story short, this is a "rule by fear" environment, and extremely micromanaged.  I wouldn't recommend this position to anyone unless you've been out of work for months and are desperate.

job_title: Audio Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Paid lunches, and students generally appreciate what you do.  The instructors are great at what they do, but hindered by management.  Sad to see so many of them leaving over the last year.  Only other pro is I am out of there finally.
cons: Low pay, terrible management, expected to use vacation time/sick days for holidays, constantly being given more responsibility with no recognition and no raise in pay for 4 years+, stood by and watched over half the staff laid off or fired while shortly after they hired recent graduates to be instructors?  Current instructors are leaving as fast as they can find jobs, and the new program is seriously flawed thanks to micro management and people being put in positions they are not qualified for due to favoritism.  Complete lack of communication in upper management and supervisory staff.  There is no ladder to climb, or room for growth, and they will cap your "salary" right at the legal minimum where you can  not charge overtime, even though they will expect you to work it.  The people leaving positive reviews, all seem to be working at the Florida branch of Full Sail, so maybe it's better down there, but LA is in need of serious changes in morale and policy.

job_title: Online Instructor in Orlando, FL
pros: I can't speak for the F2F program but I'm in the online department and it's basically my dream job. Decent pay, great benefits, and fun, easy work. Get to work from home and inspire students to grow creatively. The pay is somewhat lower than a nearby state university would start you out but the work environment makes up for it. And you have some time and energy to make money on the side if you want. Because our terms are one month we don't get summers off but the workload isn't super-demanding like it is at a traditional school to make up for it. And another thing I like is that I personally haven't experienced any office politics.
cons: I'm an Online Instructor and an extrovert so I miss teaching F2F sometimes! It's not easy making a 'presence' as an online instructor so you have to try and connect with the students somehow in your own way. I find that they appreciate a lot of encouragement. Online learning isn't easy for everyone!

review_title: Dynamic, rewarding and family friendly work environment

job_title: Student Workder in Hollywood, CA
pros: fast paced, fun, exposer, quick learning

job_title: Tour Guide in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Decent benefits for full time, coworkers are great. Lots of room to move upwards.
cons: Pay could be better as well as communication between staff and department heads

job_title: Teacher in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good pay, good benefits, good staff
cons: None, really. You gotta work, same as any job.

job_title: Studnet in Los Angeles, CA
pros: people and staff are great. really flexible schedule
cons: cannot think anything to be really honest

job_title: Customer Service Route Driver in Sacramento, CA
pros: nothing to really rate the school
cons: Making loopholes for students to pass their courses.

job_title: Admissions in Hollywood, CA
pros: I work with incredibly positive people. I am inspired daily by both the staff and the students, and feel truly fortunate that I am able to contribute to the next generation of Entertainment Industry professionals that will create movies, games, music and enhance the business in whole. The college is energized with 3000+ active students and I am constantly in awe of the thousands of alumni that are making their mark on Hollywood because of their education at LAFS. The staff is made up of incredible professionals. The support between the internal departments has never been better. The mission is to help others and that is the best motivation for an incredible team of people.
cons: The college is experiencing growth which means it is a critical time to find employees that will support the vision with passion and commitment like those that make LAFS great today.

job_title: Online Admissions Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: Used to be a team with culture. Director was great and helped out. Gifts for winning. Overtime hours. Loved the team from the past.
cons: Changed when it was all about the starts. Director changed for the worst and people didn't like the change because it started to become numbers to him. The culture is lost and there is no more personality with coworkers since they have left. How he handled coworkers resigning was immature on his part. It's now a revolving "call center" door where yes you can work there but don't expect long term commitment since you will have to perform based on your numbers. There's no communication and the other departments are working against you since they have salary. He also liked to talk about other coworkers to others to try to see what they were saying which is illegal.

review_title: Dead End Job - do not recommend
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: casual dress. gift days between Christmas to New Years.
cons:
company offers low pay (significantly below market) & no raises

department head isn't management material - doesn't know how to lead and inspire team; too much ego; undervalues staff and makes it clear that everyone is dispensable which lowers morale (of course, work flow will never halt from loss of any member, but a good leader rallies the team & makes staff feel like their contributions to the department are important/necessary); offers no room for growth

management is a joke - hard to respect someone who doesn't show respect, lacks knowledge of staff's duties, and focuses most efforts on things of minimal importance

job_title: Online Admissions Representative in Winter Park, FL
pros:
This company is great! Online programs and technology makes this admissions position fun! My Director is really good, great training and knows what is going on. I've been in the industry for many years, with a few different schools, none really compare. Goals are normal in this business, just like in any business I know Executives and Owners make those calls and knew what I signed up for. I feel the company has a direct interest in my well being. In happy to work hard for the cause! 

I also love the office setup and vibe. Team is super helpful and attentive. Already had a team outing, pretty cool.
cons: Perhaps more communication with other departments. Admissions works in teams and we meet frequently. Not really sure how Finical Aid works?

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Co-workers on my team were great. The students are the best. HR always made time for my questions and when she interviewed me she was very direct about how hard the role can be but that with the right management and training, she believed I would be great for the role. IT and facilities were really helpful when I started and always made sure I had what I needed. Salary was kind of low for sales but good benefits.
cons: The admissions management team was sneaky. A lot of favoritism. If the manager of the dept. likes you, you get whatever you want. If she doesn’t, your life will be a nightmare. Only way to please her is to kiss up to her.

job_title: Peer Advisor in Hollywood, CA
pros: I love working at The Los Angeles Film school, I have grown in my professionalism, creativity, and leadership, I'm grateful for the opportunity to work with some amazing people. Everyone that works there is extremely smart, educated, the staff really care about the students success,  and that is very important for the continued growth and success of the establishment.
cons: The Con for me would be that this position was temporary, so it will be ending soon; it's definitely bittersweet that I will be leaving because I enjoyed my experience so much. However, I'm happy and ready to see want the future holds for my professional career and wish continued blessings and prosperity to The Los Angeles Film School.

review_title: The Management seems to be running the recording school into the ground!
job_title: Instructor in West Hollywood, CA
pros: health Ins. even for part timers.  keeping current on the latest software.  the recording school is a great place due to Steve Miller the director of the program.
cons: They don't pay well. The problem is that the management has tied Steve Miller's hands in multiple areas.  They also keep trying to harvest low income students to get federal loan dollars in the door but they are the worst kind of student & they are hiding the failure of these  students by pushing them through and not allowing a failing grade or drug use to stop them from advancing to the next term.

review_title: Good job, but many problems with this company, unfortunately.
job_title: Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Teaching is fun, and you learn a lot by teaching and the questions you get asked by students.  Co-workers are solid.  The school is starting to attract better students to the recording program after years of too many students who didn't show up or showed up late, or were disrespectful, or were just after a piece of paper and did not see value in learning.  The school offers full-time positions, health benefits, vacation days, sick days, so a grade above what many of the other similar schools around LA sadly offer.
cons:
Instructors feel unappreciated, no raises for 4-5 years yet we have increased workloads, which increases resentment.  With more than 40 instructors laid off (about 70% of the recording instructor staff) in the past two years,  everyone fears that they may be next.  Instructors who have taught a certain class for years find one day that someone else has re-written their class without having been asked for any input whatsoever, adding further tension between instructors and management.  Extremely poorly managed marketing and admissions department, so enrollment has been low for years, and yet the management is extremely slow to make changes to move away from the Univ of Phoenix model of high volume. 

This company is a business who happens to run a school, there does not seem to be any real concern for students or a quality education coming from the people in charge -- the dominant theme we are told is to maintain retention, meaning don't fail any students -- unfortunately the school has made a lot of money the past five years off of students who took government loans but were never good students before they enrolled, so how could they be expected to be disciplined, show up to class, concentrate  and study -- meaning how could they not fail?  There are good students here, but there should be more of them.  The sales department pays some of their employees $80K, but most instructors make half that.   The CEO of the school owns multiple mansions while most music/recording instructors have trouble paying rising Los Angeles area rents.

review_title: It's a great steady paying job with potential to move up.  It's a very creative environment to work in.
job_title: Instructor in Hollywood, CA
pros: The people in the teaching dept. are the best reason to work there.   Hours were consistent.  Weekends off.   Relaxed atmosphere.   Equipment up to date, always working with the latest stuff.    Education through the job.  Sponsorships with software companies.
cons: Negative students on occasion.   Raises weren't consistent.   Upper management not in tune with staff's needs.   Office politics.

review_title: Insufficient Job Placement for Paying Students
job_title: in West Hollywood, CA
pros: Friendly colleagues, convenient location, clean restrooms (sometimes supplied with hand soap)
cons: Seriously under payed for all the hard work, inter-company dating brings drama into the workplace, students are provided the same lack luster events every month, the company owners don't seem to care about their employees. There are too many economically poor students attending the school who take out loans for a oversaturated industry.

job_title: Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Everyone i have met in the last nine months seems to genuinely like working here.
All the faculty have practical, real-world experience in the field.
At least in the bachelor's degree program, the students are motivated about learning and their career.
Management cares and communicates well with employees.
cons: While most of the faculty are full-time (teaching two courses), if you can only get one class, it's a tough salary to survive on.  The $35/hour (in 2014) equates to about $30K/year.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great company culture, awesome events if you're into music and Film, owners are generous during holidays (paid holiday leave in December). They tend to hire young adults, which makes for a fun environment to work in.
cons: Leadership structure is ambiguous. Rules and company protocol can be relaxed for some and enforced for others. Seems that relationships with management can get you further than others. No pay increases, although it's talked about often. No set schedules for employee reviews.

review_title: Profitable firm, low pay, great environment and people.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great people, great environment, good product. Creative atmosphere, enjoyed the work.
cons: Low pay, Many great employees are barely making ends meet.

review_title: Low pay, frustrating management, but an overall easy gig if you're teaching the right classes
job_title: Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- From time to time there are a few bright students who are great to work with.
- Sometimes theres autonomy in the classes you teach
cons:
- No raises
- Low pay

- Management can be difficult to work with

job_title: in Winter Park, FL
pros: Flexible schedule, company outings, and that’s about it
cons: If you are expecting professionalism and organization this is not the place for you. Management is a joke, they have no idea what they are doing, you do not get compensated for going above and beyond yet it’s expected, place seems to be a revolving door, only take the job if your desperate

job_title: Instructor in Hollywood, CA
pros: The students are mostly great people.
cons: Too many to list, but most significant is that everyone is severly underpaid, except for upper management, who have no idea what the students actually need to learn, and who are only concerned for their bottom line.

job_title: Online Admissions Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: The only pro I can give is that the school itself is actually good, so the product we are selling is great. As an employee, it was horrible.
cons:
Terrible pay rate and lies. Coming into the job, I had just received a raise my my former employer, as part of my agreement to join the LA Online team, they agreed to pay me the rate I had been given as a raise at my former job. This did not happen. Upon reminding my boss he assured me it was an oversight, and would be rectified with back pay. Ultimately after months of back and forth, I was told they couldn't warrant a raise because they didn't have the budget. Upon arguing this was not a raise but an error they were supposed to correct, they just denied it. 
Generally speaking they vastly under pay their online admissions team. They also have refused to give ANY raises, regardless of how great the employees performance is, based on the fact they don't feel they are making enough money. On the flip side, the higher ups use company money to fly across the country and stay in the most expensive hotels they can find. Distribution of money is going to kill this company fast. If you are thinking of taking a job here, especially in the online division, just don't. In the time I worked there several people quit, and others were laid off or fired. In the first year of the online team 8 people on a team of 15 have left.

review_title: Do yourself a favor and don't waste your time
job_title: Online Admissions Representative in Orlando, FL
pros:
Occasional enrollment contests for time off.

DOA sends Papa Johns daily coupons, you know the ones anyone can sign up to get? Such a kind gesture.

If you like to be motivated through fear, this is the ideal environment for you.
cons:
Management is clueless and unrealistic while they rake in huge salaries. 

Constant changes from corporate that make our jobs more difficult. No finger on the pulse of what we really need to get the job done.

When suggestions are brought to directors, you are scoffed and looked down upon because you're just a rep.

If you are a manager you can apparently just let money walk right out the door. They are too busy taking long lunches together, coming in late, and leaving early every day. 

No value in retention of employees or cultivating future managers. Get on the DOA's good side by tattling on your coworkers on a consistent basis. This is encouraged. 

Smoke and mirrors regarding pay and advancement opportunities, but you'll hear management talk about how much they could pay you if they wanted to.

Doesn't matter if you are a great employee and produce consistently, you will not be valued. 

Not enough finance reps to handle the front end business, yet you are accountable for your starts. More and more financial aid responsibility is being put on admissions daily.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Free movie screenings, friendly staff. It's great being able to work with students and see them graduate and make something of themselves.
cons: There aren't any cons that I can think of. I really enjoy working at the school. Everyone is super helpful and you get to positively contribute to society by helping educate the future.

job_title: Instructor in Los Angeles, CA

cons: Execs don't have a good feel for what's going on ground level. Highly political. If you happen to work on the audio side (in the other building) expect a high turnover rate.

review_title: The decision is yours to make.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The company believes in promoting from within and pushing employees to strive for more. They even offer a scholarship so employees can further there education for free.
cons: Now that they are growing at a rapid pace, they need to think bigger.

job_title: Office Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Free movies, industry events, and nice people.  The staff is very creative and artistic.  People working at the school actually do have a connection to the industry.
cons: Depressing work environment.  Company is very profit driven.  They will take two positions and mold them to fit one position.  Poor management.  HR does not resolve conflicts.  Happiness and well-being of worker not considered.

review_title: Los Angeles Film School, an inclusive and friendly company
job_title: Associate Program Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Diverse and friendly working environment. Amazing student body
